question: Will the eighth Starship integrated flight test reach an altitude of 160 kilometers before March 10, 2025?
description:
*This question is part of the* [*Bridgewater Forecasting Contest*](https://www.metaculus.com/bridgewater/)*. To be eligible to win prizes in the competition you must register for the tournament. The last day to register is March 24, 2025. Sign up or check your registration status* [*here*](https://www.metaculus.com/bridgewater/)*.*

***

[Starship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SpaceX_Starship) is a two stage launch vehicle being developed by SpaceX consisting of a [Super Heavy booster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SpaceX_Super_Heavy) as the first stage and the [Starship spacecraft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SpaceX_Starship_\(spacecraft\)) as the second stage. SpaceX [describes Starship](https://www.spacex.com/vehicles/starship/) as "the world’s most powerful launch vehicle ever developed, capable of carrying up to 150 metric tonnes fully reusable and 250 metric tonnes expendable."

So far Starship has undergone [seven "integrated flight tests"](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Starship_launches), two in 2023, four in 2024, and one in 2025 using the new Block 2 ship design. The ship of the latter flight exploded over the Turks and Caicos Islands during initial burn, likely due to a fuel leak.
fine_print:
* The question will resolve according to information published by SpaceX, including telemetry displayed during its livestream (provided Metaculus has no reason to believe the displayed telemetry is in error), or reported by [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions). In the event the altitude achieved is near 160 km but it is not clear whether 160 km was reached, Metaculus may wait for confirmation of the final altitude achieved to resolve the question. If on March 25, 2025, Metaculus determines that there is not sufficient evidence available to determine whether Starship reached an altitude of 160 km the question will be **annulled**. A statement from SpaceX or reporting from credible sources saying that Starship reached an altitude of "approximately 160 kilometers" or "\~160 kilometers" or similar will be sufficient to resolve the question as **Yes**, so long as the estimated altitude is 160 kilometers or more.
* The Starship will be considered to be "intact" even if it has minor damage or defects, so long as it remains largely whole.
news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Falcon Heavy's Historic First Flight: A Journey to Mars and Beyond**
The first test flight of the SpaceX Falcon Heavy rocket took place on February 6, 2018, from launch pad 39A at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The flight placed a Tesla Roadster, attached to the second stage, into solar orbit, reaching as far as the orbit of Mars. The Falcon Heavy is composed of three reusable first-stage boosters of the Falcon 9, linked together side by side. The combination created the most powerful operational rocket of the time, with its 27 Merlin engines combined generating over 5 million pounds of thrust, sufficient to place 141,000 pounds in a low-inclination Earth orbit or send 37,000 pounds to Mars. The demonstrative Falcon Heavy took off from launch pad 39A in the local afternoon of February 6, 2018. After burnout and separation, the two lateral boosters performed spectacular parallel landings in zones 1 and 2 of the Cape Canaveral Air Force Station, renamed Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in December 2020. Two of the central core's engines did not ignite for the landing burn, preventing the recovery of that stage on the drone ship in the Atlantic Ocean. For this demonstration flight, the Falcon Heavy carried a Tesla Roadster as the sole payload, fixed permanently to the second stage. Behind the wheel of the Tesla was a mannequin nicknamed Starman, wearing a SpaceX launch and re-entry suit. The upper stage of the Falcon Heavy, with the Tesla attached, entered an elliptical parking orbit around the Earth, passing through the Van Allen radiation belts of the planet. The onboard cameras continued to transmit live images of Starman and the Tesla against the backdrop of the Earth until the batteries ran out four hours after launch. Two hours later, the second stage reignited to send this and the Tesla into an heliocentric orbit with its farthest point beyond the orbit of Mars.
Original language: it
Publish date: February 06, 2025 04:16 AM
Source:[meteoweb.eu](https://www.meteoweb.eu/2025/02/6-febbraio-2018-primo-lancio-razzo-falcon-heavy/1001742130/)

**Damage to Atmosphere from Starship Explosion Comparable to Meteorite Falls**
The explosion of the upper stage of the Starship at an altitude of 146 km has caused damage to the atmosphere comparable to that of meteorite falls. The exact environmental damage is difficult to assess, as it is unclear how much of the rocket burned up in the atmosphere and how much fell into the ocean. Fortunately, the stage was made of stainless steel, not aluminum, which would have released toxic aluminum oxide into the ozone layer upon burning. However, the release of nitrogen oxides from the destruction of objects at hypersonic speeds can also have a negative impact on the atmosphere. Researchers note that these assessments are preliminary, but the incident has already raised questions about the long-term impact of space launches on the Earth's ecology.
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 05, 2025 06:58 PM
Source:[Рамблер](https://news.rambler.ru/tech/54160097-uscherb-atmosfere-ot-vzryva-starship-sopostavim-s-padeniem-meteoritov/)

**Boeing Reports Record Loss Due to Starliner Spacecraft Program**
Boeing reported a record loss of $523 million in 2024 due to the Starliner spacecraft program. The company cited 'delays in schedule and higher costs for testing and certification, as well as post-certification missions' as the reasons for the loss. Boeing warns of a risk of additional losses in the future. The Starliner spacecraft, which competes with SpaceX's Crew Dragon, has only had one successful crewed launch on June 5, 2024, carrying astronauts Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams. However, the spacecraft malfunctioned, leaving the astronauts stranded on the International Space Station for an extended period. They are expected to return to Earth in the spring using the Crew Dragon spacecraft. In contrast, SpaceX is making progress with its Starship program, which aims to create a reusable spacecraft. Although a recent test flight ended in a explosion, the company was able to recover the lower part of the rocket, which is considered a success. Elon Musk plans to use Starship for a manned mission to Mars in the future.

**Boeing's Starliner Program Suffers Record Losses, SpaceX Leads the Way**
Boeing has announced that its Starliner spacecraft has incurred a record $523 million loss in 2024, surpassing the program's two billion dollar expenditure. The company attributes this to 'delays in schedule and high costs for testing, certification, and post-certification missions'. Boeing warns of potential additional losses in the future. The Starliner, which competes with SpaceX's Crew Dragon, has only completed one manned launch on June 5, 2024, with astronauts Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams on board. However, a malfunction left them stranded on the International Space Station for an extended period. They are expected to return to Earth in the spring using the Crew Dragon. In contrast, SpaceX, led by Elon Musk, is making significant progress with its Starship program, focusing on developing a reusable system. Although a recent test flight ended in a explosion, the company successfully returned the lower stage of the rocket to Earth, a notable achievement. Musk plans to use Starship for Mars colonization, with SpaceX aiming to launch five unmanned missions to Mars within two years.

**More than half a billion dollars burned by Starliner in 2024**
Boeing's CST-100 Starliner project has incurred a reach-forward loss of $523 million, taking total losses beyond $2 billion. The loss is primarily due to schedule delays, higher testing and certification costs, and higher costs for post-certification missions. According to the filing, 'During 2024, we increased the reach-forward loss by $523 million, primarily to reflect schedule delays and higher testing and certification costs as well as higher costs for post certification missions.' The company warned that the loss might not be the end of the story, and said that 'Risk remains that we may record additional losses in future periods.' Boeing has not provided a date for when Starliner will launch again, nor has it said whether it will repeat the Crewed Test Flight in light of the thruster problems and the capsule's uncrewed return to Earth. A Boeing spokesperson stated, 'NASA has not yet identified a Starliner launch date or mission type.'

**NASA's Europa Clipper on its way to Jupiter's icy moon shares first images of stars from space**
NASA's Europa Clipper mission is on its way to Jupiter's icy moon Europa, with 1.6 billion miles left to travel before reaching its destination in 2030. The spacecraft's star trackers are capturing images of distant stars to help with navigation, ensuring the spacecraft is correctly oriented. These trackers are crucial for maintaining proper communication with Earth and are functioning well after launch. The mission will conduct 49 flybys of Europa to study its icy surface and hidden ocean, with the goal of determining whether the moon could support life. Europa Clipper carries nine scientific instruments, including imaging systems to map the moon's ridges and valleys. The spacecraft will use Mars' gravity to gain speed on March 1 and continue its journey to Europa.

**SpaceX set to launch Falcon 9 rocket sparking deafening sonic booms - watch live**
SpaceX is set to launch a Falcon 9 rocket from pad 39A at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Central Florida, targeting a 54-minute window from 6:13pm to 7:07pm local time. The mission will deploy the third pair of Maxar's WorldView Legion high-resolution satellite imagery into orbit. According to the Space Force's 45th Weather Squadron, the chances of favourable launch weather are greater than 95%. The launch comes after a previous attempt in March last year was cancelled due to engine issues. Elon Musk's company is also recovering the booster for a rare land recovery. Musk previously praised his team after the successful launch of the Starship spacecraft, which reached orbital speeds of 17,500 miles per hour and splashed down in the Indian Ocean.

**Blue Origin's New Shepard Completes Successful Suborbital Flight**
The reusable American rocket New Shepard, owned by Blue Origin, successfully completed a suborbital flight to an altitude of around 100 km as part of a test mission for future lunar flights. According to Space.com, the rocket was launched on February 4th as part of mission NS-29 to conduct scientific experiments for future lunar expeditions. The launch took place from the Corn Ranch launch site near the city of Van Horn in western Texas at 11:00 EST (19:00 MSK). The flight lasted around 10 minutes, after which the capsule successfully landed on Earth, while the rocket returned to the landing site about 7 minutes later. It was initially planned to launch on January 28th, but the flight was postponed due to unfavorable weather conditions and issues with the rocket's avionics. Blue Origin's New Shepard has previously completed a suborbital flight with a commercial crew of six space tourists from the US and Canada in November last year. The company, founded by billionaire Jeff Bezos, has been leading the commercial space tourism industry since 2021, followed by Virgin Galactic's Richard Branson. They have conducted several suborbital flights to an altitude of 100 km, with up to six people on board.

**SpaceX Receives Permission for Eighth Starship Test Flight**
SpaceX has received permission from the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) to conduct the eighth test flight of the Starship heavy-lift rocket. The test is scheduled to take place between February 24 and August 24, 2025. This is after the seventh test flight on January 17, 2025, ended in failure, with the Super Heavy B14 booster being recovered using the 'Mechazilla' system, but the Starship itself being lost, burning up in the atmosphere. The FAA temporarily suspended SpaceX's license to launch Starship due to the debris causing civilian aircraft to alter their routes.

**SpaceX Receives Permission for Eighth Starship Test Flight**
SpaceX has received permission from the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) to conduct the eighth test flight of the Starship heavy-lift rocket. The test is scheduled to take place between February 24 and August 24, 2025. Although the window is large, the actual test is expected to take place in early March. The seventh test flight on January 17 was unsuccessful, with the Super Heavy B14 booster being recovered using the 'Mehazilla' system, but the Starship spacecraft was lost, burning up in the atmosphere. As a result, the FAA temporarily suspended SpaceX's license to launch Starship due to the debris it left behind, which forced dozens of civilian aircraft to change their routes. As SpaceX CEO Elon Musk said, 'This time it will work.'

**Starship's Seventh Flight: A Step Towards Mars**
On January 16, 2025, the seventh flight of Starship launched at 16:37 (local time in Starbase, Texas). The Super Heavy booster and Starship separated at T+2:40, at an altitude of 91 kilometers. The Booster 14 (B14) was captured without issues by the Mechazilla tower. The 71-meter-long rocket was caught with the giant robotic arms. It is the second Super Heavy to be recovered. Despite one of the central engines failing in a previous maneuver, all engines were successfully ignited. SpaceX reused a Raptor engine from the flight number 5. The Starship 33 (S33) exploded at T+8:26, at an altitude of 146 km, due to a fire caused by a propellant leak in the rear of the ship. Elon Musk believes that a new Starship will be ready to fly in a month. Musk stated that his company will launch the first mission to Mars. 'The first spacecraft to Mars will launch within two years, when the next Earth-Mars transfer window opens. There will be no crew to check the reliability of a damage-free landing on Mars,' he said. The B14/S33 combination measures 123.1 meters, the tallest rocket in history. As Elon Musk said, 'It's like going to Mars without a rocket.' In Honduras, 4 out of 10 school-age children do not attend a school. No country can progress without education.
Original language: es
Publish date: January 22, 2025 08:01 PM
Source:[laprensa.hn](https://www.laprensa.hn/opinion/columnas/a-marte-sin-cohete-CG23704996)

**Starship’s seventh test flight fails after mid-flight fire causes spectacular explosion**
SpaceX's Starship test flight on January 16, 2025, from Starbase, Texas, ended in failure after a mid-flight fire caused a spectacular explosion over the Gulf of Mexico. The spacecraft reached an altitude of 146 km (90 miles) and a velocity of 21,320 km/h (13,245 mph) before contact was lost. Although the booster was successfully caught by the launch tower, the upper stage was destroyed. Preliminary assessments suggest that leaking fuel may have increased pressure within a cavity above the engine firewall. The test mission carried 10 satellite mockups designed to simulate a real payload deployment. SpaceX spokesman Dan Huot said, 'It was great to see a booster come down, but we are obviously bummed out about ship.' Elon Musk tweeted, 'Success is uncertain, but entertainment is guaranteed!' The failure is a setback for SpaceX's ambitious plans to use Starship for interplanetary travel, including missions to the Moon and Mars.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 17, 2025 06:09 PM
Source:[watchers.news](https://watchers.news/2025/01/17/starships-seventh-test-flight-fails-after-mid-flight-fire-causes-spectacular-explosion/)

**SpaceX's Starship Rocket Partially Fails in Seventh Integrated Flight Test**
SpaceX's seventh integrated flight test of the Starship rocket, owned by Elon Musk, partially failed: the Ship capsule exploded in flight 8 minutes and 26 seconds after launch, at 8:26 pm on January 16, 2025. The Starship rocket, the largest and most powerful ever built, is designed to return humans to the Moon (as part of NASA's Artemis program) and then to Mars. The test aimed to replicate all that had been done successfully in previous attempts, including the automatic capture of the booster with robotic arms (which was successful), and the release of a cargo of fake Starlink satellites into space. Unfortunately, something went wrong. The booster was captured successfully about 7 minutes after launch, but at T+8:26 minutes from liftoff, SpaceX lost contact with the Ship capsule, which is the upper part of Starship. According to preliminary reconstructions by SpaceX, a loss of propellant caused the progressive shutdown of the Starship engines and then the disintegration of the capsule, which exploded in flight at 8:26 pm on January 16, 2025. The explosion occurred at an altitude of about 150 km over the Caribbean, with the debris subsequently re-entering and burning up in the atmosphere over the Lesser Antilles, as shown in the spectacular video posted by Musk himself on X. SpaceX is collaborating with the FAA (the US agency responsible for civil aviation) to understand the reasons for the test failure, but the Musk company has already announced that this setback will not cause any delay in the upcoming test programs of Starship scheduled for 2025. 'We will add a new and refined fire suppression system and valves with increased capacity,' said SpaceX. 'These tests are crucial to identify all possible scenarios and ensure the safety of future human missions.'
Original language: it
Publish date: January 17, 2025 04:06 PM
Source:[geopop.it](https://www.geopop.it/spacex-la-navicella-di-starship-esplode-e-si-incendia-in-volo-cose-successo/)

**Space-X's Starship Loses Contact and is Destroyed During Seventh Test Flight**
Space-X's Starship, a 120-meter-tall reusable rocket, lost contact and was destroyed during its seventh test flight on Thursday. The rocket reached an altitude of 145 kilometers and a speed of 21,000 kilometers per hour before communication was lost. According to Bloomberg, this was the shortest test flight since November 2023, when the rocket failed after just eight minutes. The goal of the test was to deploy ten dummy satellites into space, simulating the placement of Starlink satellites. The rocket's heat shield, propulsion system, and flight computer were improved for this flight, and a used engine was also used for the first time. Space-X said that the rocket was 'demolished quickly and unexpectedly', and that engineers will investigate the cause. According to Space News, parts of the Starship crashed over the Bahamas. The long-term goal is to make the Starship completely reusable.
Original language: de
Publish date: January 17, 2025 01:53 AM
Source:[sueddeutsche.de](https://www.sueddeutsche.de/wirtschaft/starship-musk-bezos-spacex-li.3184647)

**Starship's Seventh Test Flight: A Crucial Mission with Multiple Upgrades and Tests**
The seventh test flight (IFT-7) of the Starship is scheduled to take place on January 14, 2025. Although the mission appears to be similar to the previous two, there are significant changes to the test. The second-generation Starship has undergone major modifications, including a 25% increase in internal fuel capacity, a reduction in the size of the front wing, and a slight rearward movement. This should significantly reduce the exposure of the front wing to high-temperature plasma during re-entry, simplify the insulation layout, and avoid the 'burn-through' issues seen in previous tests. The Starship has also been upgraded with repeated use in mind, including improved navigation systems, additional batteries and power systems, and increased camera numbers. SpaceX has also integrated Starlink, navigation, and wireless backup communication systems to provide stable communication and high-quality live streaming. IFT-7 will also test various special metal insulation bricks, including one with active heat dissipation. The landing sensor on the launch tower has been reinforced to prevent damage from the impact of the rocket. The test will also attempt to recover and reuse the Raptor engine, which has been used in IFT-5. Additionally, the Starship will carry 10 Starlink V3 'simulators' to test the deployment of satellites. However, due to the failure to reach orbit, all these tests will be conducted in a sub-orbital environment and will be destroyed in the atmosphere shortly after release. The final test will be the re-ignition of the Raptor engine in space, which is essential for future orbit insertion and departure.
Original language: zh
Publish date: January 10, 2025 09:14 AM
Source:[Yahoo News (Taiwan)](https://tw.news.yahoo.com/starship-ift-7-changes-090017884.html)

**Starship Completes Four Test Flights in 2024, Sets Stage for Mars Mission**
The Starship, a massive and powerful rocket, has completed four new flights in the past year. The 124-meter-tall rocket, with a power equivalent to 33 Boeing 747 jets, is crucial for plans to return humans to the Moon and eventually send them to Mars. The first test flight of the year took place on March 14, building on the success of the previous flight and adding new features such as a fuel transfer test in orbit. However, the test ended in failure when the Starship exploded at 65 kilometers due to re-entry into the Earth's atmosphere. The second test flight on June 6 was more successful, with the rocket's heat shield resisting the heat and completing its space journey. The third test flight on October 13 saw the debut of the 'Mechazilla', a giant robotic arm that successfully captured the rocket's booster. The final test flight on November 19 was intended to repeat the 'caza' maneuver, but a problem with the tower prevented it from happening. Despite this, the tests will accelerate next year to meet Elon Musk's goal of launching five Starships to Mars in 2026.
Original language: es
Publish date: January 04, 2025 11:23 PM
Source:[El Diario Vasco](https://www.diariovasco.com/sociedad/ciencia/cuatro-vuelos-coloso-espacio-20250105001320-nt.html)

**Watch SpaceX Starship test fire engines ahead of flight 7 launch (video)**
SpaceX conducted a successful engine test for its next Starship launch, known as Integrated Flight Test-7 (IFT-7), ahead of its planned launch on January 11. The test, which lasted approximately 10 seconds, was a part of a series of checkouts to ensure the vehicle is healthy before being transported to the launchpad. Once mated with its Super Heavy booster, the Starship stack will be 400 feet tall, with the Starship upper stage alone standing taller than the Statue of Liberty. SpaceX aims to make Starship the first fully reusable rocket in history, with both the Super Heavy booster and Starship upper stage designed for return and fast refurbishment. The company has already made significant progress, with four test flights in 2024 and plans to ramp up to 25 launches in 2025. NASA has contracted Starship to land astronauts on the moon during the Artemis 3 mission, expected to launch in 2027.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 16, 2024 06:03 PM
Source:[Space.com](https://www.space.com/space-exploration/launches-spacecraft/watch-spacex-starship-test-fire-engines-ahead-of-flight-7-launch-video)

**Starship Prepares for 7th Flight: A Step Towards Sustainable Space Exploration**
SpaceX has successfully conducted a static fire test of the Starship's upper stage (6 Raptor engines) at the Starbase facility in Texas, paving the way for the next integrated flight test of the system, expected to take place by January 2025. The test was shared on social media, showing the upper stage being transported to the test site and then undergoing the static fire test. Although the official launch date has not been confirmed, a NASA communication to the FAA suggests that January 11 could be the designated launch day. Starship is a revolutionary spacecraft that can be completely reused, with both the upper stage and the Super Heavy booster designed to return to the launch site and be caught in mid-air using a 'chopsticks' system. This approach reduces costs and preparation times for future flights, a crucial step towards a more sustainable access to space. SpaceX has demonstrated the potential of the Starship system in previous flights, but also faced challenges, such as communication issues during the 6th flight. Despite these difficulties, the progress made in 2024 shows the company's commitment to perfecting the system. The 7th flight of Starship will be the first launch of 2025, continuing the accelerated pace of missions established in 2024. The success of Starship is not only important for SpaceX, but also for the future of global space exploration. The NASA has selected Starship as the lunar landing module for the Artemis III mission, which will return astronauts to the Moon's surface. Additionally, the spacecraft is destined to play a key role in future missions to Mars and beyond.
Original language: it
Publish date: December 16, 2024 05:51 AM
Source:[meteoweb.eu](https://www.meteoweb.eu/2024/12/starship-accende-motori-nuovo-test-7-volo-foto-e-video/1001715068/)

**SpaceX Prepares for Seventh Starship Launch, With More Planned for 2025**
SpaceX is preparing to launch its Starship rocket for the seventh time in the coming month. The company has recently conducted a static fire test for the Super Heavy stage and has now prepared the upper stage of Starship for its own tests. According to a post on X, 'Starship is ready for testing before the seventh flight', with photos showing the Starship vehicle moving to the test stand at the Starbase facility in southern Texas. SpaceX has not announced a date for the upcoming integrated flight test (IFT), but an email from NASA to the Federal Aviation Administration has identified January 11 as a potential target. When the upper stage of Starship is stacked on top of Super Heavy, the combined vehicle stands at approximately 400 feet (122 meters) tall, making it the largest rocket ever built. Starship is the first fully reusable launch vehicle; both Super Heavy and Ship are designed to return to their respective launch sites and be caught by a Starship recovery tower. SpaceX attempted to catch Super Heavy during IFT-5, which launched in October, and succeeded; the arms caught the returning booster perfectly. The company wanted to attempt another catch of the Super Heavy booster during IFT-6, which launched on November 19, but communication issues with the tower ruined that attempt, and Super Heavy instead made a controlled water landing in the Gulf of Mexico. IFT-7 will be the first launch of Starship in 2025, and this year saw four Starship launches spread across March, June, October, and November, doubling the number of Starship launches compared to 2023.
Original language: ar
Publish date: December 15, 2024 03:20 AM
Source:[nafeza2world.com](https://www.nafeza2world.com/Tknwlwjya/2018461)

**SpaceX Prepares for Seventh Starship Launch, Targets January 11 for Integrated Flight Test**
SpaceX is preparing to launch its Starship rocket for the seventh time, with the company stating that the rocket is 'ready for testing before the seventh flight'. The company has shared photos of the Starship spacecraft moving to the test stand at its Starbase facility in southern Texas. While SpaceX has not announced a specific date for the upcoming integrated flight test (IFT), a NASA email to the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) suggests a possible target date of January 11. When the Starship upper stage is stacked on top of the Super Heavy booster, the combined vehicle stands at approximately 400 feet (122 meters) tall, making it the tallest rocket ever built. The Starship upper stage, known as Ship, measures 165 feet (50 meters) tall on its own. Starship is the first fully reusable launch vehicle, with both Super Heavy and Ship designed to return to their respective launch sites and be caught by a Starship recovery tower. SpaceX attempted to catch Super Heavy during IFT-5 in October, which was successful, but the company's attempt to catch the booster during IFT-6 in November was thwarted by communication issues, forcing Super Heavy to make a controlled water landing in the Gulf of Mexico. IFT-7 will be the first Starship launch of 2025, following four Starship launches in 2024, and is expected to increase the number of Starship launches in the coming year.

**SpaceX Prepares for Seventh Starship Launch, Targets January 11 for Integrated Flight Test**
SpaceX is preparing for the seventh launch of its Starship rocket, which is expected to take place in the coming month. The company has recently conducted a static fire test for the Super Heavy stage and has now prepared the upper stage of Starship for its own tests. According to a post on X, 'Starship is ready for testing before the seventh flight', with photos showing the Starship vehicle moving to the test stand at the Starbase facility in southern Texas. The exact date of the integrated flight test (IFT) has not been announced by SpaceX, but a NASA email to the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has identified January 11 as a potential target. When the Starship upper stage is stacked on top of Super Heavy, the combined vehicle reaches a height of approximately 400 feet (122 meters), making it the tallest rocket ever built. The upper stage, known as Ship, is 165 feet (50 meters) tall on its own. Starship is the first fully reusable launch vehicle; both Super Heavy and Ship are designed to return to their respective launch sites and be caught by a Starship recovery tower. SpaceX attempted to catch Super Heavy during IFT-5, which launched in October, and succeeded; the arms caught the returning booster perfectly. The company wanted to attempt another catch of the Super Heavy booster during IFT-6, which launched on November 19, but communication issues with the tower ruined that attempt, and Super Heavy instead made a controlled water landing in the Gulf of Mexico. IFT-7 will be the first Starship launch of 2025, and this year has seen four Starship launches, spread across March, June, October, and November, doubling the number of Starship launches compared to 2023. It is expected that the number of Starship launches will increase in 2025, as Starship has met the operational qualification requirements.
Original language: ar
Publish date: December 14, 2024 08:13 PM
Source:[sahafahh.net](https://arab.sahafahh.net/story/21780588/%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%B9%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%AA-spacex-%D9%84%D8%A5%D8%B7%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%82-%D8%B5%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%AE-starship-%D9%84)

**SpaceX rolls 7th Starship spacecraft out for testing ahead of next launch (photos)**
SpaceX's Starship megarocket is preparing for its seventh launch, expected within the next month. The upper stage, known as Ship, has been prepped for testing and is set to be stacked atop the Super Heavy first-stage booster. According to NASA, the likely target date for the integrated test flight (IFT) is January 11. When fully assembled, the Starship vehicle stands at nearly 400 feet tall, making it the largest rocket ever built. SpaceX aims to make the Starship launch reusable, with both the Super Heavy and Ship designed to return to their launch sites and be caught mid-air by the launch tower's 'chopstick arms'. The company has successfully caught a returning booster in the past, and is working towards operational qualification for the Starship vehicle, which has been tapped by NASA as the lunar lander for the Artemis 3 mission to the moon.

Publish date: December 13, 2024 07:36 PM
